Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: Variation in nuclear shape is observed in mutants impaired in LINC components or in plant-specific proteins found at the nuclear envelope. Among them are the plant functional homologs of lamins (KAKU4, NEAP, and CRWN1–4) [null], as well as human MZT1 homologs, gamma-tubulin protein complex3 (GCP3) interacting proteins (GIPs) 1 and 2 [null]. GIP1 and GIP2 are associated to microtubule nucleation complexes via the GCP3 [null, null]. Later on, they were also found to be associated to centromeric chromatin [null, null] (see nullA)see<insert> <insert>. Here, we explore the relation between nuclear stiffness and morphology in the multicellular context of the Arabidopsis root tip. Combining hyperosmotic stress, gip1gip2 mutations, nuclear shape, and micro-rheometric measurements, as well as RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) analysis, we show that nuclear stiffness and touch gene expression scale with the osmotic environment of the cell. In addition, we show that plants defective in GIP proteins exhibit this response constitutively, correlating with an increased ability of the plant to resist hyperosmotic stress.

Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: In the surviving WT cells, nuclei were strongly deformed upon treatment with 0.4 and 0.6 M mannitol, when compared to iso-osmotic control, showing nuclear circularity of 0.81± 0.01 and 0.84 ± 0.01, respectively compared to control (0.85 ± 0.01) as well as nuclear area of 31.9 ± 1.4 <delete>µ<delete> and 28.6 ± 1.1, respectively compared to control (43.7 ± 1.7 (n control = 38; n 0.4 M = 39; n 0.6 M = 41; p values for control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M are 2.903e−9 and 1.51e−6 and 1.60e−10 and 3.58e−10 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullC and 3D). Furthermore, when compared to 0.3 M mannitol (nullC and 1E), nuclear circularity was even more reduced at 0.4 M mannitol (p = 0.038), although the nuclear area was lower at 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). This suggests that a maximum of nuclei deformation exists in the WT and that gip1gip2 already reaches it in control conditions.

data.instruction:
Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

Edit: In the surviving WT cells, nuclei were strongly deformed upon treatment with 0.4 and 0.6 M mannitol, when compared to iso-osmotic control, showing nuclear circularity of 0.81± 0.01 and 0.84 ± 0.01, respectively compared to control (0.85 ± 0.01), as well as nuclear area of 31.9 ± 1.4 and 28.6 ±1.1 ,<delete>µ<delete>,respectively compared to control (43.7 ± 1.7) (n control = 38; n 0.4 M = 39; n 0.6 M = 41; p values for control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M are 2.903e−9 and 1.51e−6 and 1.60e−10 and 3.58e−10 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullC and 3D). Furthermore, when compared to 0.3 M mannitol (nullC and 1E), nuclear circularity was even more reduced at 0.4 M mannitol (p = 0.038), although the nuclear area was lower at 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). This suggests that a maximum of nuclei deformation exists in the WT and that gip1gip2 already reaches it in control conditions.

data.instruction:
Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei, showing values of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei w<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>when compared to WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

data.instruction:
Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei, showing values of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei w<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>when compared to WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

data.instruction:
Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei. The 2C WT and 2C gip1gip2 nuclei presented nuclear area of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuc<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>uclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei when compared to 2C WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei, showing values of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei w<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>when compared to WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

Edit: In the surviving WT cells, nuclei were strongly deformed upon treatment with 0.4 and 0.6 M mannitol, when compared to iso-osmotic control, showing nuclear circularity of 0.81± 0.01 and 0.84 ± 0.01, respectively compared to control (0.85 ± 0.01), as well as nuclear area of 31.9 ± 1.4 and 28.6 ±1.1µm2,  respectively compared to control (43.7 ± 1.7) (n control = 38; n 0.4 M = 39; n 0.6 M = 41; p values for control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M are 2.903e−9 and 1.51e−6 and 1.60e−10 and 3.58e−10 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullC and 3D). Furthermore, when compared to 0.3 M mannitol (n<delete>nuclear circularity of 0.85 ± 0.01, nuclear area of 32.1 ± 1.0 µ<delete>(nuclear circularity of 0.85 ± 0.01, nuclear area of 32.1 ± 1.0 (nullC and 1E), nuclear circularity was even more reduced at 0.4 M mannitol (p = 0.038), although the nuclear area was lower at 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). This suggests that a maximum of nuclei deformation exists in the WT and that gip1gip2 already reaches it in control conditions.,

Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: In the surviving WT cells, nuclei were strongly deformed upon treatment with 0.4 and 0.6 M mannitol, when compared to iso-osmotic control, showing nuclear circularity of 0.81± 0.01 and 0.84 ± 0.01, respectively compared to control (0.85 ± 0.01), as well as nuclear area of 31.9 ± 1.4 and 28.6 ±1.1µm2,  respectively compared to control (43.7 ± 1.7) (n control = 38; n 0.4 M = 39; n 0.6 M = 41; p values for control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M are 2.903e−9 and 1.51e−6 and 1.60e−10 and 3.58e−10 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullC and 3D). Furthermore, when compared to 0.3 M mannitol (circularity of 0.85 ± 0.01, area of 32.1 ± 1.0 <delete> <delete> (nullC and 1E), nuclear circularity was even more reduced at 0.4 M mannitol (p = 0.038), although the nuclear area was lower at 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). This suggests that a maximum of nuclei deformation exists in the WT and that gip1gip2 already reaches it in control conditions.

data.instruction:
Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei. The 2C WT and 2C gip1gip2 nuclei presented nuclear area of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nu<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>uclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei when compared to 2C WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

data.instruction:
Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei, showing values of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei w<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>when compared to WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

Edit: In the surviving WT cells, nuclei were strongly deformed upon treatment with 0.4 and 0.6 M mannitol, when compared to iso-osmotic control, showing nuclear circularity of 0.81± 0.01 and 0.84 ± 0.01, respectively compared to control (0.85 ± 0.01), as well as nuclear area of 31.9 ± 1.4 and 28.6 ±1.1µm2,  respectively compared to control (43.7 ± 1.7) (n control = 38; n 0.4 M = 39; n 0.6 M = 41; p values for control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M are 2.903e−9 and 1.51e−6 and 1.60e−10 and 3.58e−10 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullC and 3D). Furthermore, when compared to 0.3 M mannitol (n<delete>nuclear circularity of 0.85 ± 0.01, nuclear area of 32.1 ± 1.0 µ<delete>(nuclear circularity of 0.85 ± 0.01, nuclear area of 32.1 ± 1.0 (nullC and 1E), nuclear circularity was even more reduced at 0.4 M mannitol (p = 0.038), although the nuclear area was lower at 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). This suggests that a maximum of nuclei deformation exists in the WT and that gip1gip2 already reaches it in control conditions.,

data.instruction:
Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei. The 2C WT and 2C gip1gip2 nuclei presented nuclear area of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nu<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>uclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei when compared to 2C WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

data.instruction:
Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei, showing values of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei w<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>when compared to WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

Edit: In the surviving WT cells, nuclei were strongly deformed upon treatment with 0.4 and 0.6 M mannitol, when compared to iso-osmotic control, showing nuclear circularity of 0.81± 0.01 and 0.84 ± 0.01, respectively compared to control (0.85 ± 0.01), as well as nuclear area of 31.9 ± 1.4 and 28.6 ±1.1µm2,  respectively compared to control (43.7 ± 1.7) (n control = 38; n 0.4 M = 39; n 0.6 M = 41; p values for control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M are 2.903e−9 and 1.51e−6 and 1.60e−10 and 3.58e−10 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullC and 3D). Furthermore, when compared to 0.3 M mannitol (n<delete>nuclear circularity of 0.85 ± 0.01, nuclear area of 32.1 ± 1.0 µ<delete>(nuclear circularity of 0.85 ± 0.01, nuclear area of 32.1 ± 1.0 (nullC and 1E), nuclear circularity was even more reduced at 0.4 M mannitol (p = 0.038), although the nuclear area was lower at 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). This suggests that a maximum of nuclei deformation exists in the WT and that gip1gip2 already reaches it in control conditions.,

Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei. The 2C WT and 2C gip1gip2 nuclei presented nuclear area of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuclei exhibit signi<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>it significantly smaller nuclei when compared to 2C WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

Edit: In the surviving WT cells, nuclei were strongly deformed upon treatment with 0.4 and 0.6 M mannitol, when compared to iso-osmotic control, showing nuclear circularity of 0.81± 0.01 and 0.84 ± 0.01, respectively compared to control (0.85 ± 0.01), as well as nuclear area of 31.9 ± 1.4 and 28.6 ±1.1µm2,  respectively compared to control (43.7 ± 1.7) (n control = 38; n 0.4 M = 39; n 0.6 M = 41; p values for control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M are 2.903e−9 and 1.51e−6 and 1.60e−10 and 3.58e−10 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullC and 3D). Furthermore, when compared to 0.3 M mannitol <delete>(nuclear circularity :0.85 ± 0.01 and area of 32.1 ±1.0 µ <delete>M mannitol (nuclear circularity :0.85 ± 0.01 and area of 32.1 ±1.0 (nullC and 1E), nuclear circularity was even more reduced at 0.4 M mannitol (p = 0.038), although the nuclear area was lower at 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). This suggests that a maximum of nuclei deformation exists in the WT and that gip1gip2 already reaches it in control conditions.

data.instruction:
Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independently of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei. The 2C WT and 2C gip1gip2 nuclei presented nuclear area of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 <clearSubscript><clearSubscript> nuclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei when compared to 2C WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

Edit: In the surviving WT cells, nuclei were strongly deformed upon treatment with 0.4 and 0.6 M mannitol, when compared to iso-osmotic control, showing nuclear circularity of 0.81± 0.01 and 0.84 ± 0.01, respectively compared to control (0.85 ± 0.01), as well as nuclear area of 31.9 ± 1.4 and 28.6 ±1.1µm2,  respectively compared to control (43.7 ± 1.7) (n control = 38; n 0.4 M = 39; n 0.6 M = 41; p values for control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M are 2.903e−9 and 1.51e−6 and 1.60e−10 and 3.58e−10 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullC and 3D). Furthermore, when compared to 0.3 M mannitol <delete>( <delete> (nuclear circularity of 0.85 ± 0.01, nuclear area of 32.1 ± 1.0 (nullC and 1E), nuclear circularity was even more reduced at 0.4 M mannitol (p = 0.038), although the nuclear area was lower at 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). This suggests that a maximum of nuclei deformation exists in the WT and that gip1gip2 already reaches it in control conditions.,

Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei, showing values of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei w<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>when compared to WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: In the surviving WT cells, nuclei were strongly deformed upon treatment with 0.4 and 0.6 M mannitol, when compared to iso-osmotic control, showing nuclear circularity of 0.81± 0.01 and 0.84 ± 0.01, respectively compared to control (0.85 ± 0.01), as well as nuclear area of 31.9 ± 1.4 and 28.6 ±1.1µm2,  respectively compared to control (43.7 ± 1.7) (n control = 38; n 0.4 M = 39; n 0.6 M = 41; p values for control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M are 2.903e−9 and 1.51e−6 and 1.60e−10 and 3.58e−10 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullC and 3D). Furthermore, when compared to 0.3 M mannitol (nuclear circularity :0.85 ± 0.01 and area <insert>:<insert>of 32.1 ± 1.0 (nullC and 1E), nuclear circularity was even more reduced at 0.4 M mannitol (p = 0.038), although the nuclear area was lower at 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). This suggests that a maximum of nuclei deformation exists in the WT and that gip1gip2 already reaches it in control conditions.

data.instruction:
Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei. The 2C WT and 2C gip1gip2 nuclei presented nuclear area of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nu<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>uclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei when compared to 2C WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei. The 2C WT and 2C gip1gip2 nuclei presented nuclear area of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuc<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>uclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei when compared to 2C WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei. The 2C WT and 2C gip1gip2 nuclei presented nuclear area of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuclei exhibit signi<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>it significantly smaller nuclei when compared to 2C WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

Edit: In the surviving WT cells, nuclei were strongly deformed upon treatment with 0.4 and 0.6 M mannitol, when compared to iso-osmotic control, showing nuclear circularity of 0.81± 0.01 and 0.84 ± 0.01, respectively compared to control (0.85 ± 0.01), as well as nuclear area of 31.9 ± 1.4 and 28.6 ±1.1µm2,  respectively compared to control (43.7 ± 1.7) (n control = 38; n 0.4 M = 39; n 0.6 M = 41; p values for control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M are 2.903e−9 and 1.51e−6 and 1.60e−10 and 3.58e−10 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullC and 3D). Furthermore, when compared to 0.3 M mannitol (n<delete>nuclear circularity of 0.85 ± 0.01, nuclear area of 32.1 ± 1.0 µ<delete>(nuclear circularity of 0.85 ± 0.01, nuclear area of 32.1 ± 1.0 (nullC and 1E), nuclear circularity was even more reduced at 0.4 M mannitol (p = 0.038), although the nuclear area was lower at 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). This suggests that a maximum of nuclei deformation exists in the WT and that gip1gip2 already reaches it in control conditions.,

Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independent of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei. The 2C WT and 2C gip1gip2 nuclei presented nuclear area of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuclei exhibit signi<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>it significantly smaller nuclei when compared to 2C WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

Edit: In the surviving WT cells, nuclei were strongly deformed upon treatment with 0.4 and 0.6 M mannitol, when compared to iso-osmotic control, showing nuclear circularity of 0.81± 0.01 and 0.84 ± 0.01, respectively compared to control (0.85 ± 0.01), as well as nuclear area of 31.9 ± 1.4 and 28.6 ±1.1µm2,  respectively compared to control (43.7 ± 1.7) (n control = 38; n 0.4 M = 39; n 0.6 M = 41; p values for control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M are 2.903e−9 and 1.51e−6 and 1.60e−10 and 3.58e−10 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullC and 3D). Furthermore, when compared to 0.3 M mannitol (circularity of 0.85 ± 0.01, area of 32.1 ± 1.0 <delete> <delete> (nullC and 1E), nuclear circularity was even more reduced at 0.4 M mannitol (p = 0.038), although the nuclear area was lower at 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). This suggests that a maximum of nuclei deformation exists in the WT and that gip1gip2 already reaches it in control conditions.

Edit: In the surviving WT cells, nuclei were strongly deformed upon treatment with 0.4 and 0.6 M mannitol, when compared to iso-osmotic control, showing nuclear circularity of 0.81± 0.01 and 0.84 ± 0.01, respectively compared to control (0.85 ± 0.01), as well as nuclear area of 31.9 ± 1.4 and 28.6 ±1.1µm2,  respectively compared to control (43.7 ± 1.7) (n control = 38; n 0.4 M = 39; n 0.6 M = 41; p values for control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M are 2.903e−9 and 1.51e−6 and 1.60e−10 and 3.58e−10 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullC and 3D). Furthermore, when compared to 0.3 M mannitol <delete>(nuclear circularity :0.85 ± 0.01 and area of 32.1 ±1.0 µ <delete>M mannitol (nuclear circularity :0.85 ± 0.01 and area of 32.1 ±1.0 (nullC and 1E), nuclear circularity was even more reduced at 0.4 M mannitol (p = 0.038), although the nuclear area was lower at 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.019). No significant differences were observed between 0.4 M and 0.6 M mannitol (p = 0.094 and 0.075, respectively, for nuclear circularity and area; nullC and 3D). This indicates a threshold in the response to hyperosmotic stress for the WT. In contrast, the gip1gip2 nuclear shapes remained unchanged in these harsher osmotic conditions (n control = 58; n 0.4 M = 22; n 0.6 M = 43; p values, control versus 0.4 M and control versus 0.6 M, are 0.33 and 0.61 and 0.99 and 0.53 for nuclear circularity and area, respectively; nullE and 3F). This suggests that a maximum of nuclei deformation exists in the WT and that gip1gip2 already reaches it in control conditions.

Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independently of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei. The 2C WT and 2C gip1gip2 nuclei presented nuclear area of 31.1 ± 2.1 µm2 and 21.4 ± 1.8 µm2, respectively. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 <clearSubscript><clearSubscript> nuclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei when compared to 2C WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

Action: ClearSubscript
Note: This edit could not be executed, so it is carried out as an instruction for production team to act on. No further action is required from your side on this.
Edit: The gip1gip2 knocked down mutant is impaired in the recruitment of microtubule nucleation complexes and centromeric chromatin architecture, leading to ploidy defects [null, null] (nullA). The mutant also exhibits severe developmental defects. Root growth is altered and is variable from mild to strong phenotype (nullA). As previously shown, root meristem nuclei from gip1gip2 SUN1-GFP seedlings exhibit shape defects [null] (nullB) that resemble that of wild-type (WT) nuclei under hyperosmotic stress (nullB). To go beyond this qualitative comparison, we characterized the nuclear shape of the mutant. Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independently of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei when compared to 2C WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>9; p = 0.0014; nullF). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.

Nuclear circularity in gip1gip2 was equal to 0.78 ± 0.013 (n = 74; nullD), which was significantly lower than the untreated WT (0.936 ± 0.001; n = 99; p = 2.19e−26; see nullC). However, nuclear area was increased in gip1gip2 and reached 63.8 ± 3.545 μm2 on average (n = 74; nullE) to compare to 41.1 ± 0.758 μm2 in untreated WT (n = 99; p = 9.79e−12; see nullD). Increased average nuclear area may relate to increased ploidy levels in the mutant [null, null]. In order to compare nuclear area between WT and mutant independently of ploidy, we analyzed the area of WT and gip1gip2 nuclei in 2C flow-sorted root nuclei. This revealed that 2C gip1gip2 nuclei exhibit significantly smaller nuclei when compared to 2C WT nuclei (n 2C WT = 18 and n 2C gip1gip2 = 19; p = 0.0014; nullF)<clearSubscript><clearSubscript>F). This demonstrates that gip1gip2 has more compact nuclei than the WT nuclei. This confirms that gip1gip2 nuclei fully mimic WT nuclei under hyperosmotic stress, at least from a geometric standpoint.
